text: Good morning, today is Monday, June 12.

I'm Korva Coleman, from NPR News, 
and here are today's top stories:

Italian media mogul and former Prime Minister 
Silvio Berlusconi died today at the age of 86,

according to the TV network he owns. NPR's 
Sylvia Poggioli reports Berlusconi dominated

Italian politics for more than two decades, 
but his political career ended in ignominy:

"Berlusconi was Italy's wealthiest person — he 
owned TV networks, newspapers, publishing houses,

a top soccer team and much more. When scandals 
toppled the political establishment in the 1990s,

Berlusconi filled the vacuum; his new 
party swept to power promising Italians

prosperity and low taxes. He became 
Italy's longest serving prime minister,

but with his permi-tan, hair transplants and 
facelifts, he was shunned on the international

stage. He survived multiple corruption 
trials and tawdry tales of orgies,

but he was forced from power in 2011 by the 
European debt crisis. Three years later,

he was ousted from Parliament, following his 
conviction for evading some $10 million in taxes.
"Sylvia Poggioli, NPR News, Rome."

President Biden is meeting today at the White 
House with NATO's outgoing Secretary General,
Jens Stoltenberg. As NPR's Asma Khalid reports,

their meeting comes amidst uncertainty 
over who will become NATO's next leader:

"Stoltenberg is due to step down later this year 
— he's already extended his term more than once.

The White House has not publicly said who the 
United States would support as a successor,

but it's praising Stoltenberg 
for maintaining stability:

'The president remains very grateful 
and appreciative of the leadership
of Jens Stoltenberg as Secretary General.'

"John Kirby is a spokesman 
with the Biden administration:

'He's just done a masterful job — particularly 
when you look at what the alliance has

been able to do — unilaterally, sometimes 
bilaterally — in terms of supporting Ukraine.'

"NATO members will meet in Lithuania 
next month, and a big question is who

will lead this transatlantic alliance 
as Russia's war with Ukraine continues.
"Asma Khalid, NPR News."

Ukraine says its forces have retaken 
a small village from Russian forces.

It's part of Ukraine's long-anticipated 
counteroffensive operation against the Kremlin.

Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro says 
he'll issue a disaster declaration

today to help speed repairs to an overpass 
on Interstate 95 in Philadelphia. Shapiro

says it buckled yesterday after a big fuel 
truck caught fire underneath the freeway:

"The northbound side of I-95 
has completely collapsed,

and the southbound side is not structurally 
sound to carry any traffic over it."

Officials haven't said what caused the fire, 
and it's not clear if anyone was hurt. The

overpass collapse will seriously affect traffic 
on the East Coast — I-95 is a major north-south

freeway. Shapiro says the section of the overpass 
that fell carries about 160,000 vehicles daily.
This is NPR.
